Write a short summary for the following passage:
Media playback is not supported on this device
After four of the seven events, defending champion Ennis-Hill, 30, leads by 72 points from young Belgian Nafi Thiam, with Barbados's Akela Jones a further 21 points back.
Johnson-Thompson, 23, had led going into the evening session, only for a disastrous shot put of 11.68m to drop her back.
Thiam's emergence adds a new dimension to the battle that began as a showdown between the two Britons, with world silver medallist Brianne Thiesen Eaton down in sixth, 186 points off the lead.
Four years ago, Ennis-Hill was 184 points ahead going into the second day, while at the World Championships a year ago she held an overnight lead of 80 over Johnson-Thompson.
Here in the Estadio Olimpico she moved back into first place with a time of 23.49 seconds in the day's final event, the 200m.
It leaves her in promising shape as she looks to retain the title she won in such memorable style in London four years ago.
"It's been a mixed day. l was really happy with my hurdles and high jump. I was obviously disappointed with my shot put - that was frustrating," she said.
"I was a bit down on the 200m but generally happy.
"I need to rest up and come back strong tomorrow. I'm trying to enjoy it but it's very stressful."
Johnson-Thompson will expect to eat into Ennis-Hill's advantage in the long jump, Saturday's first event at 15:45 BST, but Ennis-Hill has historically had the better javelin.
The Britons are evenly matched over the 800m, while Thiam is expected to drop back in that final event.
Ennis-Hill had run 12.84 seconds in winning her 100m hurdles heat to give herself an early edge and then cleared 1.89m in the high jump.
That was her best height since the 2012 Olympic trials, and meant she had made her highest scoring start to a heptathlon since she gave birth to son Reggie two years ago.
But Johnson-Thompson then went clear at a new British record of 1.98m, having clocked 13.48 in the hurdles, to storm into the lead.
And when Thiam also cleared 1.98m - a height no heptathlete has ever matched - that put the 21-year-old Belgian into second.
Johnson-Thompson went into the evening session on 2,264 points, an advantage of 12 over Thiam and 22 on Ennis-Hill, only for that sub-standard shot to drop her back to sixth.
The event has always been a weakness, but this was a metre and a half down on her personal best, and Thiam's third-round 14.91m pushed her briefly into top spot, Ennis-Hill's 13.86 enough for second overall.
But Thiam is a better jumper and thrower than runner, and 25.10 for third in the first 200m heat cost her as she chases her first major international medal.
"I was thrilled with my high jump. After the 200m I'm a bit down," said Johnson-Thompson.
"The 200m is one of my strongest events and I really wanted to drop under 23 seconds.
"They keep you out in the cold a long time but that's no excuse, it's the same for everyone but maybe that's why the times are down."
Media playback is not supported on this device
In the 800m, Britain's Michael Rimmer, at his third Olympics yet seeking to make his first final, qualified well from a heat containing reigning champion and world record holder David Rudisha.
There was disappointment for team-mate Elliot Giles, seventh in the fourth heat, but both Laura Muir and Laura Weightman are into the semi-finals of the 1500m.
Matt Hudson-Smith qualified comfortably from his 400m heat yet there was no progression for Martyn Rooney, left distraught by a poor run for fifth in the second semi-final.
The 400m hurdles semi-finals are on Saturday, with Britain's Eilidh Doyle and Meghan Beesley in contention for a place in the final.
There is also a British interest in the 4x10

Johnson-Thompson will expect to eat into Ennis-Hill's advantage in the long jump, Saturday's first event at 15:45 BST, but Ennis-Hill has historically had the better javelin.
The Britons are evenly matched over the 800m, while Thiam is expected to drop back in that final event.
Ennis-Hill had run 12.84 seconds in winning her 100m hurdles heat to give herself an early edge and then cleared 1.89m in the high jump.
That was her best height since the 2012 Olympic trials, and meant she had made her highest scoring start to a heptathlon since she gave birth to son Reggie two years ago.
But Johnson-Thompson then went clear at a new British record of 1.98m, having clocked 13.48 in the hurdles, to storm into the lead.
And when Thiam also cleared 1.98m - a height no heptathlete has ever matched - that put the 21-year-old Belgian into second.
Johnson-Thompson went into the evening session on 2,264 points, an advantage of 12 over Thiam and 22 on Ennis-Hill, only for that sub-standard shot to drop her back to sixth.
The event has always been a weakness, but this was a metre and a half down on her personal best, and Thiam's third-round 14.91m pushed her briefly into top spot, Ennis-Hill's 13.86 enough for second overall.
But Thiam is a better jumper and thrower than runner, and 25.10 for third in the first 200m heat cost her as she chases her first major international medal.
"I was thrilled with my high jump. After the 200m I'm a bit down," said Johnson-Thompson.
"The 200m is one of my strongest events and I really wanted to drop under 23 seconds.
"They keep you out in the cold a long time but that's no excuse, it's the same for everyone but maybe that's why the times are down."
Media playback is not supported on this device
In the 800m, Britain's Michael Rimmer, at his third Olympics yet seeking to make his first final, qualified well from a heat containing reigning champion and world record holder David Rudisha.
There was disappointment for team-mate Elliot Giles, seventh in the fourth heat, but both Laura Muir and Laura Weightman are into the semi-finals of the 1500m.
Matt Hudson-Smith qualified comfortably from his 400m heat yet there was no progression for Martyn Rooney, left distraught by a poor run for fifth in the second heat.
And there was no improvement on the 100m for James Dasaolu, who finished sixth in his heat.
"I'm gutted. I've been working hard, I've been training hard, I've been doing everything I can," said Das

Write a short summary for the following passage:
Media playback is not supported on this device
After four of the seven events, defending champion Ennis-Hill, 30, leads by 72 points from young Belgian Nafi Thiam, with Barbados's Akela Jones a further 21 points back.
Johnson-Thompson, 23, had led going into the evening session, only for a disastrous shot put of 11.68m to drop her back.
Thiam's emergence adds a new dimension to the battle that began as a showdown between the two Britons, with world silver medallist Brianne Thiesen Eaton down in sixth, 186 points off the lead.
Four years ago, Ennis-Hill was 184 points ahead going into the second day, while at the World Championships a year ago she held an overnight lead of 80 over Johnson-Thompson.
Here in the Estadio Olimpico she moved back into first place with a time of 23.49 seconds in the day's final event, the 200m.
It leaves her in promising shape as she looks to retain the title she won in such memorable style in London four years ago.
"It's been a mixed day. l was really happy with my hurdles and high jump. I was obviously disappointed with my shot put - that was frustrating," she said.
"I was a bit down on the 200m but generally happy.
"I need to rest up and come back strong tomorrow. I'm trying to enjoy it but it's very stressful."

In the 800m, Britain's Michael Rimmer, at his third Olympics yet seeking to make his first final, qualified well from a heat containing reigning champion and world record holder David Rudisha.
There was disappointment for team-mate Elliot Giles, seventh in the fourth heat, but both Laura Muir and Laura Weightman are into the semi-finals of the 1500m.
Matt Hudson-Smith qualified comfortably from his 400m heat yet there was no progression for Martyn Rooney, left distraught by a poor run for fifth in the third heat.
And there was more disappointment for Britain in the 50km walk, where Tom Bosworth finished 21st and Tom Walsh 24th.
